name: Project
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Project
description:
Project

Projects are top-level containers in Google Cloud Platform. They store information about billing and authorized users, and they contain BigQuery data. Each project has a friendly name and a unique ID.

Google::Cloud::Bigquery::Project is the main object for interacting with Google BigQuery. Google::Cloud::Bigquery::Dataset objects are created, accessed, and deleted by Google::Cloud::Bigquery::Project.

See Google::Cloud#bigquery.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

methods.name: name
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Project#name
methods.description: The descriptive name of the project. Can only be present if the project was retrieved with #projects.

methods.name: numeric_id
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Project#numeric_id
methods.description: The numeric ID of the project. Can only be present if the project was retrieved with #projects.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new(
  project: "my-project-id",
  keyfile: "/path/to/keyfile.json"
)

bigquery.project #=> "my-project-id"

methods.name: query_job
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Project#query_job
methods.description:
Queries data using the asynchronous method.

When using standard SQL and passing arguments using params, Ruby types are mapped to BigQuery types as follows:

BigQuery Ruby Notes
BOOL true/false  
INT64 Integer  
FLOAT64 Float  
STRING STRING  
DATETIME DateTime DATETIME does not support time zone.
DATE Date  
TIMESTAMP Time  
TIME Google::Cloud::BigQuery::Time  
BYTES File, IO, StringIO, or similar  
ARRAY Array Nested arrays, nil values are not supported.
STRUCT Hash Hash keys may be strings or symbols.

See Data Types for an overview of each BigQuery data type, including allowed values.

examples.caption: Query using standard SQL:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

job = bigquery.query_job "SELECT name FROM " \
                         "`my_project.my_dataset.my_table`"

job.wait_until_done!
if !job.failed?
  job.query_results.each do |row|
    puts row[:name]
  end
end

examples.caption: Query using legacy SQL:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

job = bigquery.query_job "SELECT name FROM " \
                         "[my_project:my_dataset.my_table]",
                         legacy_sql: true

job.wait_until_done!
if !job.failed?
  job.query_results.each do |row|
    puts row[:name]
  end
end

examples.caption: Query using positional query parameters:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

job = bigquery.query_job "SELECT name FROM " \
                         "`my_dataset.my_table`" \
                         " WHERE id = ?",
                         params: [1]

job.wait_until_done!
if !job.failed?
  job.query_results.each do |row|
    puts row[:name]
  end
end

examples.caption: Query using named query parameters:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

job = bigquery.query_job "SELECT name FROM " \
                         "`my_dataset.my_table`" \
                         " WHERE id = @id",
                         params: { id: 1 }

job.wait_until_done!
if !job.failed?
  job.query_results.each do |row|
    puts row[:name]
  end
end

params.name: query
params.description: A query string, following the BigQuery query syntax, of the query to execute. Example: “SELECT count(f1) FROM [myProjectId:myDatasetId.myTableId]”.

params.name: params
params.description: Standard SQL only. Used to pass query arguments when the query string contains either positional (?) or named (@myparam) query parameters. If value passed is an array ["foo"], the query must use positional query parameters. If value passed is a hash { myparam: "foo" }, the query must use named query parameters. When set, legacy_sql will automatically be set to false and standard_sql to true.

params.name: priority
params.description: Specifies a priority for the query. Possible values include INTERACTIVE and BATCH. The default value is INTERACTIVE.

params.name: cache
params.description: Whether to look for the result in the query cache. The query cache is a best-effort cache that will be flushed whenever tables in the query are modified. The default value is true. For more information, see query caching.

params.name: table
params.description:
The destination table where the query results
should be stored. If not present, a new table will be created to
store the results.

params.name: create
params.description:
Specifies whether the job is allowed to create new tables. The default value is needed.

The following values are supported:

  • needed - Create the table if it does not exist.
  • never - The table must already exist. A ‘notFound’ error is raised if the table does not exist.

params.name: write
params.description:
Specifies the action that occurs if the destination table already exists. The default value is empty.

The following values are supported:

  • truncate - BigQuery overwrites the table data.
  • append - BigQuery appends the data to the table.
  • empty - A ‘duplicate’ error is returned in the job result if the table exists and contains data.

params.name: dataset
params.description:
The default dataset to use for
unqualified table names in the query. Optional.

params.name: large_results
params.description: If true, allows the query to produce arbitrarily large result tables at a slight cost in performance. Requires table parameter to be set.

params.name: standard_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s standard SQL dialect for this query. If set to true, the query will use standard SQL rather than the legacy SQL dialect. Optional. The default value is true.

params.name: legacy_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s legacy SQL dialect for this query. If set to false, the query will use BigQuery’s standard SQL dialect. Optional. The default value is false.

params.name: large_results
params.description: This option is specific to Legacy SQL. If true, allows the query to produce arbitrarily large result tables at a slight cost in performance. Requires table parameter to be set.

params.name: flatten
params.description: This option is specific to Legacy SQL. Flattens all nested and repeated fields in the query results. The default value is true. large_results parameter must be true if this is set to false.

params.name: maximum_billing_tier
params.description: Limits the billing tier for this job. Queries that have resource usage beyond this tier will fail (without incurring a charge). Optional. If unspecified, this will be set to your project default. For more information, see High-Compute queries.

params.name: maximum_bytes_billed
params.description:
Limits the bytes billed for this
job. Queries that will have bytes billed beyond this limit will fail
(without incurring a charge). Optional. If unspecified, this will be
set to your project default.

methods.name: query
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Project#query
methods.description:
Queries data using the synchronous method.

When using standard SQL and passing arguments using params, Ruby types are mapped to BigQuery types as follows:

BigQuery Ruby Notes
BOOL true/false  
INT64 Integer  
FLOAT64 Float  
STRING STRING  
DATETIME DateTime DATETIME does not support time zone.
DATE Date  
TIMESTAMP Time  
TIME Google::Cloud::BigQuery::Time  
BYTES File, IO, StringIO, or similar  
ARRAY Array Nested arrays, nil values are not supported.
STRUCT Hash Hash keys may be strings or symbols.

See Data Types for an overview of each BigQuery data type, including allowed values.

examples.caption: Query using standard SQL:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

sql = "SELECT name FROM `my_project.my_dataset.my_table`"
data = bigquery.query sql

data.each do |row|
  puts row[:name]
end

examples.caption: Query using legacy SQL:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

sql = "SELECT name FROM [my_project:my_dataset.my_table]"
data = bigquery.query sql, legacy_sql: true

data.each do |row|
  puts row[:name]
end

examples.caption: Retrieve all rows: (See QueryData#all)
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

data = bigquery.query "SELECT name FROM `my_dataset.my_table`"

data.all do |row|
  puts row[:name]
end

examples.caption: Query using positional query parameters:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

data = bigquery.query "SELECT name " \
                      "FROM `my_dataset.my_table`" \
                      "WHERE id = ?",
                      params: [1]

data.each do |row|
  puts row[:name]
end

examples.caption: Query using named query parameters:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

data = bigquery.query "SELECT name " \
                      "FROM `my_dataset.my_table`" \
                      "WHERE id = @id",
                      params: { id: 1 }

data.each do |row|
  puts row[:name]
end

params.name: query
params.description: A query string, following the BigQuery query syntax, of the query to execute. Example: “SELECT count(f1) FROM [myProjectId:myDatasetId.myTableId]”.

params.name: params
params.description: Standard SQL only. Used to pass query arguments when the query string contains either positional (?) or named (@myparam) query parameters. If value passed is an array ["foo"], the query must use positional query parameters. If value passed is a hash { myparam: "foo" }, the query must use named query parameters. When set, legacy_sql will automatically be set to false and standard_sql to true.

params.name: max
params.description:
The maximum number of rows of data to return per
page of results. Setting this flag to a small value such as 1000 and
then paging through results might improve reliability when the query
result set is large. In addition to this limit, responses are also
limited to 10 MB. By default, there is no maximum row count, and
only the byte limit applies.

params.name: timeout
params.description:
How long to wait for the query to complete,
in milliseconds, before the request times out and returns. Note that
this is only a timeout for the request, not the query. If the query
takes longer to run than the timeout value, the call returns without
any results and with QueryData#complete? set to false. The default
value is 10000 milliseconds (10 seconds).

params.name: dryrun
params.description: If set to true, BigQuery doesn’t run the job. Instead, if the query is valid, BigQuery returns statistics about the job such as how many bytes would be processed. If the query is invalid, an error returns. The default value is false.

params.name: cache
params.description: Whether to look for the result in the query cache. The query cache is a best-effort cache that will be flushed whenever tables in the query are modified. The default value is true. For more information, see query caching.

params.name: dataset
params.description:
Specifies the default datasetId and projectId
to assume for any unqualified table names in the query. If not set,
all table names in the query string must be qualified in the format
‘datasetId.tableId’.

params.name: project
params.description: Specifies the default projectId to assume for any unqualified table names in the query. Only used if dataset option is set.

params.name: standard_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s standard SQL dialect for this query. If set to true, the query will use standard SQL rather than the legacy SQL dialect. When set to true, the values of large_results and flatten are ignored; the query will be run as if large_results is true and flatten is false. Optional. The default value is true.

params.name: legacy_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s legacy SQL dialect for this query. If set to false, the query will use BigQuery’s standard SQL When set to false, the values of large_results and flatten are ignored; the query will be run as if large_results is true and flatten is false. Optional. The default value is false.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
puts dataset.name

params.name: dataset_id
params.description: The ID of a dataset.

returns.description: Returns nil if the dataset does not exist.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.create_dataset "my_dataset"

examples.caption: A name and description can be provided:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.create_dataset "my_dataset",
                                  name: "My Dataset",
                                  description: "This is my Dataset"

examples.caption: Or, configure access with a block: (See Dataset::Access)
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.create_dataset "my_dataset" do |dataset|
  dataset.access.add_writer_user "writers@example.com"
end

params.name: dataset_id
params.description:
A unique ID for this dataset, without the
project name. The ID must contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers
(0-9), or underscores (_). The maximum length is 1,024 characters.

params.name: name
params.description: A descriptive name for the dataset.

params.name: description
params.description:
A user-friendly description of the
dataset.

params.name: expiration
params.description:
The default lifetime of all tables in the
dataset, in milliseconds. The minimum value is 3600000 milliseconds
(one hour).

params.name: location
params.description: The geographic location where the dataset should reside. Possible values include EU and US. The default value is US.

params.name: yield
params.description: a block for setting rules

params.name: yield.access
params.description:
the object
accepting rules

methods.name: datasets
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Project#datasets
methods.description: Retrieves the list of datasets belonging to the project.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

datasets = bigquery.datasets
datasets.each do |dataset|
  puts dataset.name
end

examples.caption: Retrieve hidden datasets with the all optional arg:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

all_datasets = bigquery.datasets all: true

examples.caption: Retrieve all datasets: (See Dataset::List#all)
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

datasets = bigquery.datasets
datasets.all do |dataset|
  puts dataset.name
end

params.name: all
params.description: Whether to list all datasets, including hidden ones. The default is false.

params.name: token
params.description:
A previously-returned page token representing
part of the larger set of results to view.

params.name: max
params.description: Maximum number of datasets to return.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

job = bigquery.job "my_job"

params.name: job_id
params.description: The ID of a job.

returns.description: Returns nil if the job does not exist.

methods.name: jobs
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Project#jobs
methods.description: Retrieves the list of jobs belonging to the project.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

jobs = bigquery.jobs
jobs.each do |job|
  # process job
end

examples.caption: Retrieve only running jobs using the filter optional arg:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

running_jobs = bigquery.jobs filter: "running"
running_jobs.each do |job|
  # process job
end

examples.caption: Retrieve all jobs: (See Job::List#all)
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

jobs = bigquery.jobs
jobs.all do |job|
  # process job
end

params.name: all
params.description: Whether to display jobs owned by all users in the project. The default is false.

params.name: token
params.description:
A previously-returned page token representing
part of the larger set of results to view.

params.name: max
params.description: Maximum number of jobs to return.

params.name: filter
params.description:
A filter for job state.

Acceptable values are:

  • done - Finished jobs
  • pending - Pending jobs
  • running - Running jobs

methods.name: projects
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Project#projects
methods.description: Retrieves the list of all projects for which the currently authorized account has been granted any project role. The returned project instances share the same credentials as the project used to retrieve them, but lazily create a new API connection for interactions with the BigQuery service.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

projects = bigquery.projects
projects.each do |project|
  puts project.name
  project.datasets.all.each do |dataset|
    puts dataset.name
  end
end

examples.caption: Retrieve all projects: (See Project::List#all)
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

projects = bigquery.projects

projects.all do |project|
  puts project.name
  project.datasets.all.each do |dataset|
    puts dataset.name
  end
end

params.name: token
params.description:
A previously-returned page token representing
part of the larger set of results to view.

params.name: max
params.description: Maximum number of projects to return.

methods.name: time
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Project#time
methods.description: Creates a Bigquery::Time object to represent a time, independent of a specific date.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

fourpm = bigquery.time 16, 0, 0
data = bigquery.query "SELECT name " \
                      "FROM `my_dataset.my_table`" \
                      "WHERE time_of_date = @time",
                      params: { time: fourpm }

data.each do |row|
  puts row[:name]
end

examples.caption: Create Time with fractional seconds:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

precise_time = bigquery.time 16, 35, 15.376541
data = bigquery.query "SELECT name " \
                      "FROM `my_dataset.my_table`" \
                      "WHERE time_of_date >= @time",
                      params: { time: precise_time }

data.each do |row|
  puts row[:name]
end

params.name: hour
params.description: Hour, valid values from 0 to 23.

params.name: minute
params.description: Minute, valid values from 0 to 59.

params.name: second
params.description:
Second, valid values from 0 to 59. Can
contain microsecond precision.

methods.name: schema
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Project#schema
methods.description:
Creates a new schema instance. An optional block may be given to configure the schema, otherwise the schema is returned empty and may be configured directly.

The returned schema can be passed to Dataset#load using the schema option. However, for most use cases, the block yielded by Dataset#load is a more convenient way to configure the schema for the destination table.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

schema = bigquery.schema do |s|
  s.string "first_name", mode: :required
  s.record "cities_lived", mode: :repeated do |nested_schema|
    nested_schema.string "place", mode: :required
    nested_schema.integer "number_of_years", mode: :required
  end
end

dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"

gs_url = "gs://my-bucket/file-name.csv"
load_job = dataset.load "my_new_table", gs_url, schema: schema

params.name: yield
params.description: a block for setting the schema

params.name: yield.schema
params.description: the object accepting the schema
